title: Will Taylor Swiftâ€™s Kamala Harris endorsement actually matter?
content:
Taylor Swift, always noted for her flair for dramatic timing, finally endorsed Vice President Kamala Harris in the presidential race Tuesday night. 

Moments after the first debate between Harris and former President Donald Trump, Swift posted her endorsement to Instagram, with a picture of herself posing with her now almost-equally famous cat. Meanwhile, Harris walked off the stage at her post-debate party with Swiftâ€™s feminist anthem â€œThe Manâ€ blaring. The entire endorsement was a carefully choreographed move coming after nearly a year of speculation, disappointment, and paranoia from political onlookers.

â€œIâ€™m voting for @kamalaharris because she fights for the rights and causes I believe need a warrior to champion them,â€ Swift wrote, urging her followers to do their own research and make their own choices. She signed off with what appeared to be a jab at VP nominee Sen. JD Vanceâ€™s infamous â€œcat ladyâ€ sound bite: â€œTaylor Swift, Childless Cat Lady.â€ 

In the post, Swift unambiguously states that sheâ€™s voting for Harris and her running mate Gov. Tim Walz because of their support for such feminist issues as â€œLGBTQ+ rights, IVF, and a womanâ€™s right to her own body.â€ At the same time, she makes space for potentially millions of fans who might not feel the same way.

â€œIf you havenâ€™t already, now is a great time to do your research on the issues at hand and the stances these candidates take on the topics that matter to you the most,â€ Swift writes. â€œAs a voter, I make sure to watch and read everything I can about their proposed policies and plans for this country.â€ 

Her endorsement drew jubilation among some quarters, as well as vitriol in others. Elon Musk had perhaps the most bizarre and off-putting response. â€œFine Taylor â€¦ you win â€¦ I will give you a child and guard your cats with my life,â€ Musk wrote on X. 

Onlookers have been breathlessly speculating about whether and when Swift will weigh in on this election all year. In January, after Swift began her much-publicized romance with NFL star Travis Kelce, conservatives theorized that Swift was a deep-state psyop. The idea was that her relationship with Kelce was a ploy to juice her popularity so that her eventual endorsement of Joe Biden, then the Democratic nominee, would be all the more impactful. 

The same month, the New York Times reported that the Biden campaign was actively courting Swiftâ€™s endorsement, and that she was their â€œbiggest and most influentialâ€ target. â€œFund-raising appeals from Ms. Swift could be worth millions of dollars for Mr. Biden,â€ the Times noted. 

Trump, predictably, was incensed at the very idea. â€œThere’s no way she could endorse Crooked Joe Biden, the worst and most corrupt President in the History of our Country, and be disloyal to the man who made her so much money,” he posted on Truth Social in February, apparently referring to his role in signing the Music Modernization Act.

After Harris became the Democratic nominee in July, she received a slew of celebrity endorsements from the likes of Charli XCX, Megan Thee Stallion, and Cardi B. Even BeyoncÃ© gave Harris permission to use her song â€œFreedomâ€ in campaign ads, a de facto endorsement from one of the most powerfully elusive figures in pop culture. Reading the tea leaves of a possible Swift endorsement became a fever-pitched and chaotic guessing game in the months following. 

In August, rumors flew over one of Swiftâ€™s Instagram posts, in which Swift was pictured on stage at one of her concerts next to the silhouette of a strong-shouldered woman. To some observers, it looked as though Swift had photoshopped Harrisâ€™s shadow into the frame as an easter egg to let the sharp-eyed know her endorsement would be forthcoming. She hadnâ€™t: The woman was one of her backup dancers.

Some Swift fans cautioned patience. On the occasions when Swift has made political endorsements in the past, sheâ€™s usually done so relatively late in the race. In 2016, she didnâ€™t endorse at all. In 2018, she got politically involved for the first time, endorsing Democrats Phil Bredesen and Jim Cooper for Congress on October 7, two days before the voter registration deadline in Tennessee. In 2020, Swift similarly endorsed Joe Biden on October 7. Expecting an endorsement in August, her fans said, was too early for her.

Still, as the months wore on, there was a growing outcry among some of her fans. Trump shared a series of AI-generated images falsely claiming Swift had endorsed him, but Swift said nothing. Her new friend Brittany Mahomes went public with her support of Trump, but Swift publicly embraced her at the highly photographed US Open shortly thereafter. 

The fervor with which people have speculated about what Swift would do is striking, considering that celebrity political endorsements appear to be a mixed bag with relatively narrow effects. As Li Zhou has reported for Vox, celebrities can be good at getting people to pay attention to a race, or at heightening excitement about a candidate that people are already interested in, but theyâ€™re not necessarily good at changing peopleâ€™s minds across party lines. 

You might be more likely to tune into the DNC if you think Swift or BeyoncÃ© is going to show up, but thereâ€™s little evidence that their presence could turn you from an undecided voter into a committed Harris supporter. At best, celebrity endorsements might convince some otherwise unenthusiastic people at the margins to turn out and vote.

At worst, thereâ€™s some evidence that the plethora of celebrity endorsements for Hillary Clinton in 2016 hurt her rather than helped her, strengthening the sense that she was a candidate for the liberal elite. Thatâ€™s the reason Swift said she decided not to endorse Clinton. â€œâ€‹Unfortunately in the 2016 election you had a political opponent who was weaponizing the idea of the celebrity endorsement,â€ Swift told Vogue in 2019. â€œHe was going around saying, Iâ€™m a man of the people. Iâ€™m for you. I care about you. I just knew I wasnâ€™t going to help.â€

Swiftâ€™s previous political actions have generally followed the pattern you would expect from the data: good for overall political engagement, less good for any one political candidate. Sheâ€™s great at getting people to register to vote. Last year, a single Instagram story from her led to a 23 percent increase in voter registration. In 2018, a similar Instagram post led to 65,000 new registrations in 24 hours. 

Swift seems to know her strength here. Tuesdayâ€™s Instagram post endorsing Harris included a reminder to her fans to make sure theyâ€™re registered to vote, and an Instagram story linked fans to vote.gov.

Of course, even after Swiftâ€™s endorsement, Phil Bredesen handily lost his 2018 campaign for the Senate in Tennessee. Swift may have moved the needle for him, but not enough to get a Democratic senator elected in a red state. 

The 2024 presidential election is projected to be much closer. â€œBidenâ€™s electoral vote majority was a function of fewer than 50,000 votes in three states four years ago,â€ pointed out the Washington Post in August. â€œGetting a small segment of the massive Taylor Swift fan base to vote that otherwise wouldnâ€™t? Hard to dismiss the idea that it could tip the balance.â€

Still, given the mixed track record, itâ€™s fair to ask why people are so worked up about Swiftâ€™s political endorsements. 

There are basically two factors at play behind this fascination. The first is her image. The second is her stature.

Swift has played with pop feminism through much of her career. In 2014 she declared that she identified as a feminist and positioned her 1989 tour, girl squad and all, as a feminist act. When she was mocked at the Golden Globes, she declared the jokes anti-feminist. 

After her public downfall in 2016, Swift rehabilitated her image in part by leaning into politics. Her 2020 documentary Miss Americana features a scene in which Swift weeps while begging her father and management team to get on board with her endorsing Democrats for Congress. â€œI need to be on the right side of history!â€ she cries. Shortly after that encounter, she released her song â€œThe Man,â€ in which she argues that she comes in for public criticism because of her gender. 

That led many of Swiftâ€™s fans to expect her to walk the walk. The price of starting so many sentences with â€œAs a woman in this industry,â€ they argue, is that you also have to say something when the known sexual abuser who ended Roe v. Wade is running for president against a woman whoâ€™s campaigning on a platform of reproductive rights. Swiftâ€™s continued silence, even after Trump used AI to speak for her, had those fans worried.

â€œGiven â€¦ how much mileage Swift got in the past out of her decision to speak out on politics, the idea that she will remain silent would seem to make her past speaking out, at a more convenient moment, appear cynical,â€ wrote Daniel Dâ€™Addario for Variety earlier this week. â€œItâ€™d be regrettable if her engagement with the world of politics were just another of her eras, and one from which she were willing to move on.â€ 

With this new endorsement, Swift can assure her fans sheâ€™s still got her feminist cred, even as sheâ€™s phrased it carefully to give her more Trump-leaning fans room for plausible deniability. Sheâ€™s successfully beaten back charges of hypocrisy and bandwagon feminism, and her star can continue to shine.

The bigger reason so many are so concerned with Swiftâ€™s endorsement, however, is her singular stature in the pop culture landscape. Taylor Swift has been a huge star for years, but with the success of the Eras tour, sheâ€™s ascended to a new level of superstardom and cultural saturation. Political onlookers seem to think Swift has become so powerful that thereâ€™s a chance her say-so might actually swing the needle in a meaningful direction.

Swift probably wonâ€™t change the minds of many people, because no celebrity can do that. But celebrities are good at activating voters on the margins, and Swiftâ€™s reach is broad enough at this point that her impact there could make a real difference come November.

Just the possibility that she might seems to be threatening to some on the right: see Muskâ€™s response offering to â€œgive [Swift] a child.â€ 

Heâ€™s ostensibly responding to Swift calling herself a â€œchildless cat lady.â€ But thereâ€™s a crude implied threat in his offer, too: let me knock you up so you stop talking. 

In an election cycle laced with misogynistic rhetoric, Swiftâ€™s cautious, carefully phrased endorsement was enough to make her a target of threats from one of the richest men in the world. Muskâ€™s post is a tell that even Swiftâ€™s most measured political speech can be a threat to a political movement arrayed against women having control of their bodies and voices â€”Â and Swiftâ€™s voice is much louder than most.Â

title: Shrinking the economy wonâ€™t save the planet
content:
Could we solve climate change if we just accepted being dramatically poorer, forever? 

As Iâ€™ve written before, the answer is 1) no, not really, and 2) we can also solve climate change without that, and that will be better for everyone â€” especially those who are already poor â€” so we should do that instead.

But this idea has stuck around in the form of the â€œdegrowthâ€ movement, which argues that â€œeconomic growthâ€ as an objective inevitably leads to environmental destruction and that we should focus away from economic growth and toward ways to improve quality of life without it.

Degrowth has always been a bit of a moving target. Even mainstream economists will agree that GDP alone doesnâ€™t measure whether a life is meaningful and fulfilling, but they will also point out that as countries get richer, they also get healthier and happier. Is degrowth just the uncontroversial claim that what really matters is people leading good lives, or is it the wildly controversial claim that people would lead equally good lives even ifÂ we were to systematically shrink GDP in rich countries to focus on sustainability?Â 

I think a lot of people find something appealing about the rhetoric of degrowthism: anti-consumerism, a simpler life, local food, etc.Â But widespread adoption of all of those things would do approximately nothing about climate change or the other environmental issues the movement cares so much about.Â 

And while degrowth positions itself as a policy platform, itâ€™s political poison. As soon as you start getting into details, itâ€™s hard to come up with anything that polls worse than a steadily shrinking economy and the end of the conveniences of modern life. That makes it a policy agenda without any proposals about how it would become a law, an agenda that would sink any politician who attached themselves to it. (Not that youâ€™re likely to find one.)Â 

All of this combines to make the degrowth literature â€” which has by this point become an enormous body of work â€” frustrating. Degrowthers understandably expect people who want to criticize their movement to engage with its literature. One of the most frequent responses to criticism is that the critics have engaged with only a tiny fraction of the degrowth literature out there. Thatâ€™s true, but at the same time, no one can seriously engage with hundreds of papers.

But the fact that thereâ€™s so much written about degrowth doesnâ€™t mean thereâ€™s good answers hidden somewhere in the pile of papers. Iâ€™ve increasingly gotten the sense that the movementâ€™s contributors are effectively in an academic echo chamber, publishing papers that only they read and that donâ€™t address any of the reservations of their critics.Â 

A new fiercely critical review of the degrowth literature, published in the journal Ecological Economics, sums up everything thatâ€™s gone wrong. But it also offers the degrowth community the serious critical engagement it will need if it wants to move from idle speculation to a workable policy program.

Whatâ€™s wrong with the degrowth literature?

The authors analyzed 561 papers about degrowth in an effort to describe where the fieldÂ is at today. What they uncovered was profoundly discouraging.Â 

Their major takeaways: Of the 561 studies, â€œthe large majority (almost 90%) of studies are opinions rather than analysis â€¦ most studies offer ad hoc and subjective policy advice, lacking policy evaluation and integration with insights from the literature on environmental/climate policies â€¦ Data analysis is often superficial and incomplete â€¦ studies tend to not satisfy accepted standards for good research.â€

Itâ€™s rare to see a critique this stark of an entire fieldâ€™s academic literature in a respected journal that is itself within that field (Ecological Economics publishes papers on degrowth). And, to be clear, these are some extremely damning critiques. They paint a picture of a field thatâ€™s unserious about the actual standards of academic work, one flooded with papers (many of them in reasonably respected journals) but conducted totally without reference to everything we actually know about how climate, development, and policy work.Â 

Reading this review, one comes away with the impression that the degrowth literature is fundamentally unserious. The authors of the review say, â€œ[O]ne is inclined to infer that degrowth cannot (yet) be considered as a significant field of academic research.â€

The review describes paper after paper with meaninglessly tiny sample sizes: sociological interviews with 10 volunteers who make handicrafts for a charity in a town in Germany, 12 interviews with residents of a town near Barcelona about tourism, eight interviews with environmental justice leaders in Croatia. Even a healthy field will have the occasional paper with a tiny sample size or thatâ€™s methodologically shaky, but the popularity of these tiny sample-size qualitative interview-based studies is typical of a field in its infancy that hasnâ€™t yet nailed down its core questions or methodologies.Â 

Degrowthism isnâ€™t ready

All of this is a significant problem. If a policy proposal is intended to solve a problem like climate change, it needs to be put into effect worldwide within the next decade or two. Thatâ€™s not the stage of policy maturity where you publish lots of interviews with volunteers at NGOs; itâ€™s the stage of policy maturity where you are expected to have (and where the mainstream climate policy literature does have) specific by-country emissions targets, breakdowns of possible routes for that countryâ€™s energy demand to be met while those emissions targets are met, and analyses of the trajectory so far.Â 

You might expect that the field would have these struggles as it was new but would have higher-quality research as it matured. That does not appear to be the case with degrowthism, which has its origins as far back as the 1972 report â€œThe Limits to Growthâ€ by the Club of Rome. As the review authors concluded: â€œThere is also no indication that things are improving with time.â€ Recent work is just as far from meeting scientific standards as older work.Â 

None of this surprised me as someone who has tried in the past to wade through the degrowth literature for my reporting. But I am glad the review was comprehensively written up and published in a journal that people who believe in degrowth actually read.Â 

If you think that our world needs degrowth, then the horrendously poor quality of the degrowth literature isnâ€™t just annoying, itâ€™s a serious emergency.Â 

The more important a problem is, the more important it is to do high-quality, comprehensive, well-justified work on it. If degrowth ideas have something to offer the world, itâ€™s all the more important that they adhere to normal standards about how to do research.

title: How do kids have fun? Inside the state of childâ€™s play in 2024.
content:
Do kids still play?

Specifically, do they play in active, imaginative, kid-directed ways, off screens and in the real world? Itâ€™s a question Iâ€™ve gotten in many forms since I started this newsletter, from the reader who asked if kids are still learning â€œRing Around the Rosieâ€ to the dad who wondered if itâ€™s possible to give kids independence in a sometimes unsafe world. 

Such concerns arenâ€™t unwarranted. Research shows that kidsâ€™ unstructured playtime has declined significantly since the 1980s, as fears of kidnapping, traffic accidents, and violence have made parents more wary about letting their kids play outside on their own. Studies in the US, UK, and Europe have found a decrease in childrenâ€™s outdoor play in recent decades, along with an increase in screen time.

Itâ€™s true that smartphones and tablets have, at least to some degree, replaced physical games with digital ones. As any parent of a young child can tell you, â€œtechnology has changed the way kids play,â€ Ruslan Slutsky, an education professor at the University of Toledo who studies play, told me. On the one hand, kids can now play video games with people all around the world. On the other, â€œthereâ€™s been a big disappearance in general neighborhood play,â€ Slutsky said. 

Growing up in Brighton Beach, Brooklyn, in the 1950s, University of Delaware education professor Roberta Golinkoff used to play outside for hours on end, with no adult supervision in sight and technology no more advanced than an old rubber ball. â€œThat rubber ball can play a thousand games,â€ says Golinkoff, who has studied childrenâ€™s play for decades. â€œChildhood is so different now.â€

Replacing physical play with phones and iPads can be bad for kidsâ€™ gross motor skills and social development, including their ability to read faces, Slutsky said. Free, unstructured play is also necessary for developing cognitive abilities such as self-control, experts say. Some even believe that the rise in anxiety and depression among young people in recent years can be linked to decreased play.

However, Iâ€™ve also heard from experts, parents, and kids alike that kids do still play, and that the creativity that has turned rubber balls into hot potatoes and shot puts and cannon fire since time immemorial is alive and well in children today. 

But they need help from adults to make their neighborhoods safe for playing â€” and to give them the time for unstructured fun.

Why play is different now

Kidsâ€™ play started to change in the 1980s, many experts say, after a series of high-profile kidnapping cases, including the disappearance of 6-year-old Etan Patz. These cases didnâ€™t actually represent a spike in stranger kidnappings, which remain relatively rare today. But headlines about children snatched off the streets â€” alongside a short-lived but impactful campaign that placed some of their photos on the backs of milk cartons â€” struck fear in the hearts of American parents, who started keeping their kids indoors.

At the same time, parents and educators became concerned about kidsâ€™ academic performance, as a number of studies showed American students lagging behind their counterparts around the world. School years began to get longer, making summer break shorter. Recess, too, began to dwindle, with school districts in Atlanta, Chicago, and elsewhere eliminating it entirely in hopes of boosting test scores. Kids in the 1990s and 2000s simply had less free time to play than their elders.

Then came the smartphone. iPhones and iPads have taken a lot of blame for ruining American childhood, and in some cases, the evidence is weak â€” thereâ€™s no research, for example, definitively showing that social media hurts kidsâ€™ mental health. But phones and tablets have crowded out some more analog forms of fun.

â€œIn our research, we found that kids were spending a lot less time outside,â€ Slutsky said. â€œThey were spending a lot less time in traditional forms of play because they were playing with devices.â€

How kids play today

Play on devices isnâ€™t all bad. Children can use them to learn more about special interests, such as birding, Golinkoff said. (As a longtime birder, I can attest to the value of Merlin.) Meanwhile, one Norwegian researcher (and former preschool teacher) has found that young children can continue online play in the real world â€” using Minecraft concepts to play with blocks, for example â€” and take small risks in online environments that mirror the kind of unpredictable play that experts say is crucial for development.
